newsitem.title: ITALY: SOCCER-ZOLA JOINS CHELSEA FOR "TACTICAL REASONS".
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-ZOLA JOINS CHELSEA FOR "TACTICAL REASONS".

text.p: Striker Gianfranco Zola, saying he was moving to England for "tactical reasons", became Chelsea's third Italian player on Friday.
"I'm emigrating for tactical reasons," the diminutive Sardinian told a news conference after his last practice with Serie A club Parma, with whom he won the UEFA Cup in 1995.

There were no immediate details of the contract but it was reported in Italy to be for two years and worth between 11 and 12 billion lire ($6.6 to $7.2 million). Earlier reports put the deal at 13 billion lire ($7.8 million).
Zola, 30, will join compatriots Gianluca Vialli and Roberto Di Matteo at Chelsea, managed by Dutch former AC Milan player Ruud Gullit.
The Italian said his move to the English premier league club was dictated by problems at Parma, where coach Carlo Ancelotti wanted him as a right-sided midfielder rather than as an outright striker.
Parma have in-form Italian international Enrico Chiesa and Argentine Hernan Crespo, both signed in the close season, as their first-choice strikers in a two-pronged attack.
"This team was not built to keep either Crespo, Chiesa or me out of the attacking line-up," Zola said.

"But after our early elimination from the Italian and UEFA Cups the situation only got worse and I was asked to change my game, which was difficult for me to accept because I know I can contribute more in another position," he said.
Zola said he was enthusiastic about playing in England and would fly to London on Monday to meet the media.
"It will be exciting for the soccer and also culturally. I'll finally be able to learn English well," he said.
Parma said there were no hard feelings.
"The separation is by mutual agreement," said general manager Michele Uva, confirming the move. "The deal between Zola, us and Chelsea has been finalised to everyone's satisfaction."
Zola is the third player in a year to leave Parma for England. Colombian Faustino Asprilla went to Newcastle and Swede Tomas Brolin to Leeds.

Zola, who scored 49 goals in 102 league games since joining Parma in 1993, was Diego Maradona's understudy when Napoli won the league title in 1989-90. He spent four seasons at Napoli after starting out in minor league clubs in his native Sardinia.

The playmaker has been a stalwart of the Italian national team for years and was one of the few players who stood out in their 2-1 defeat by Bosnia in a friendly played in Sarajevo's Kosevo Stadium on Wednesday.

His most recent experience of playing in England was at the European championship in June when he missed a crucial eighth-minute penalty against Germany at Old Trafford, Manchester, that would have kept Italy in the competition.
